elements.title: Pre-Civilizational Curiosity: Protecting the Host's Instinctual Freedom in Discovery
elements.problem: The host arrives in discovery still in full possession of their instinctual freedom over their space. They have surrendered nothing. Freud Ch III identifies that 'our so-called civilization itself is to blame for a great part of our misery, and we should be much happier if we were to give it up and go back to primitive conditions.' The host in discovery is in those primitive conditions: autonomous, unobligated, uncommitted. Any premature demand -- registration forms, identity requests, property details -- violates the pleasure principle by imposing civilizational cost before any civilizational benefit has been demonstrated. The emotional challenge is that the platform must attract the host without triggering the instinctual alarm that says 'this system wants to take something from me.' The user stories confirm: 'Any flow that requires users to give information before seeing results will lose most of them.' The host's dominant emotion here is guarded curiosity -- they are drawn by the possibility of income but wary of what surrendering their space actually means.
elements.solution: The platform must feel like a window, not a door. Discovery should deliver value -- market demand signals, earnings estimates, neighborhood context -- without asking the host to step through any threshold. The emotional tone is generous demonstration: 'Here is what your space could earn. Here is who is looking. Here is how it works.' No registration wall. No forms. No identity requests. The copy must acknowledge the host's autonomy ('Your space, your terms') while gently surfacing the civilizational benefit ('Hosts in your area earn $X/month with vetted, working professionals'). The emotional arc of discovery is: curiosity validated, not curiosity taxed.

evidence.quote: Any flow that requires users to give information before seeing results will lose most of them. Show something useful first. Offer to refine after.
evidence.insight: Rod's principle is the surface expression of Freud's pleasure principle: the host's instinct to protect their privacy and autonomy can only be softened if the platform has already demonstrated that previous surrenders of attention produced something valuable. Discovery must be all give, no take.

evidence.quote: Our so-called civilization itself is to blame for a great part of our misery, and we should be much happier if we were to give it up and go back to primitive conditions.
evidence.insight: The host in discovery is unconsciously weighing whether this marketplace (civilization) is worth the instinctual sacrifice it will demand. Any premature ask confirms the suspicion that 'I would be better off finding someone on my own.' The emotion to protect is curiosity; the emotion to prevent is suspicion.

elements.emotion_rationale: The host has not yet committed to any civilizational sacrifice; their emotional state is open exploration, and the platform must sustain this openness by demonstrating value without demanding anything in return.

do: Lead with specific numbers: '$3,200/mo average for 2BR in your area'
Use possessive language that affirms ownership: 'your space,' 'your terms,' 'your neighborhood'
Frame the platform as a resource, not a commitment: 'See what hosts near you earn'
Acknowledge the host's current autonomy before suggesting an alternative
dont: Use urgency language in discovery ('Limited spots!' 'Sign up now!')
Ask questions before giving answers ('Tell us about your space' before showing earnings)
Use platform jargon ('lease styles,' 'periodic tenancy') before the host has context
Frame the host's current situation as a problem ('Stop leaving money on the table')
copy_guidelines.example_good: Hosts in Williamsburg earn an average of $3,200/month with vetted professionals who need a weekday space. See how your place compares.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Sign up to find out what your space is worth! Create your free account to get started.

animation_feel.feel_description: Content arrives gently, as if being offered on an open palm -- never pushed toward the host. Elements fade in with a slight upward drift, suggesting possibility rather than urgency.

tension_relief.tension_point: The moment the host wonders 'what will this platform want from me?' -- typically triggered by any call-to-action or form field
tension_relief.relief_point: Seeing concrete, local earnings data and demand signals without being asked for anything -- the platform gives before it takes
tension_relief.timing: Relief must arrive within 3 seconds of the host's first meaningful interaction with any discovery surface

personalization_signals: Show earnings data specific to the host's neighborhood (geo-detected or referral-linked)
Reference the specific property type if the host arrived via a targeted ad or agent referral
Display the referring agent's name and photo if the host clicked a personal link
Surface demand signals relevant to the host's area: 'X professionals searched for spaces near you this week'

anti_patterns.reason: Demanding identity (the first civilizational surrender) before showing value activates instinctual resistance. Freud: 'if the deprivation is not made good economically, one may be certain of producing serious disorders.' The disorder here is permanent bounce.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Create your account to see what your space could earn.

elements.title: Tentative Compliance: Easing the First Renunciation at Onboarding
elements.problem: Onboarding is the host's first act of civilizational submission: creating an account, verifying identity, connecting with an assigned agent. Freud Ch III describes how 'the members of the community have restricted their possibilities of gratification, whereas the individual recognized no such restrictions.' The host is transitioning from individual freedom to community membership. The emotional challenge is that the warm human connection from the evaluation call (with the agent) is about to be replaced by cold platform mechanics -- forms, verification steps, terms acceptance. Freud identifies an 'element of disappointment' when civilization's promises do not match its experience. If the agent call felt personal and easy, and the onboarding feels impersonal and bureaucratic, the host experiences this gap as civilizational betrayal. The dominant emotion must be reassured continuity -- the feeling that the agent is still present even as the platform takes over.
elements.solution: The onboarding experience must feel like a continuation of the agent conversation, not a handoff to a system. The agent's name and photo should be the first thing the host sees. Copy should reference the call: 'Bryant mentioned you have two units in Williamsburg. Let us get those set up.' Identity verification should be framed as protection ('This keeps your listing secure') not as compliance ('We need to verify your identity'). Every step should be accompanied by the agent's presence -- either their avatar, their name, or copy written in their voice. The emotional arc is: the human warmth of the call extends into the digital experience, and the host feels accompanied, not processed.

evidence.quote: Authentication should be invisible until it matters. Inline auth pop-up, not a full-page redirect. Users don't lose search context.
evidence.insight: Civilizational demands (identity verification, account creation) must be invisible until the host is already psychologically committed. The agent call creates that commitment; onboarding must not squander it with a jarring bureaucratic transition.

evidence.quote: Human life in communities only becomes possible when a number of men unite together in strength superior to any single individual and remain united against all single individuals. The members of the community have restricted their possibilities of gratification, whereas the individual recognized no such restrictions.
evidence.insight: Onboarding is the moment the host joins the community and accepts its 'Right' over individual freedom. The agent serves as the civilizational mediator -- making the restriction feel like an invitation rather than an imposition.

elements.emotion_rationale: The host is making their first real commitment to the platform; the dominant emotion must be trust in the human relationship that brought them here, extended seamlessly into the digital environment.

do: Reference the agent by name: 'Bryant set things up for you'
Reference specifics from the call: 'Your two Williamsburg units are ready to list'
Frame verification as protection: 'This keeps your space secure and your guests vetted'
Use first-person-plural: 'We will walk you through this' -- the agent and host together
dont: Use generic welcome language: 'Welcome to Split Lease! Let us get started'
Present verification as a requirement: 'You must verify your identity to continue'
Drop the agent's presence: no screens should feel like they are from 'the system' rather than from the agent
Front-load terms of service or legal language before the host sees their property context
copy_guidelines.example_good: Bryant mentioned your two units in Williamsburg. Let us get them set up -- we just need a quick ID check to keep things secure.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Welcome to Split Lease! Please verify your identity to create your account. Upload a government-issued photo ID.

animation_feel.feel_description: Transitions feel like a guided handshake -- steady, unhurried, with each step arriving after the previous one settles. The agent's avatar pulses subtly on first appearance, anchoring the human presence.

tension_relief.tension_point: The moment the host encounters the first impersonal platform element -- a form field, a verification step, a terms checkbox -- after the warmth of the agent call
tension_relief.relief_point: Seeing the agent's name, photo, and a reference to the call immediately above or beside the impersonal element, converting it from 'the system asks' to 'Bryant asks'
tension_relief.timing: The agent's presence must be visible within the first 2 seconds of any onboarding screen

personalization_signals: Display the agent's name and avatar throughout onboarding
Pre-fill any information the host shared during the call (property type, location, unit count)
Reference specific call moments: 'You mentioned unfurnished units -- we have pre-selected that for you'
Show a brief timeline: 'Step 1 of 3 -- most hosts finish in under 2 minutes'

anti_patterns.pattern: Generic system welcome replacing the agent's personal connection
anti_patterns.reason: The host built trust with a person, not a brand. Generic welcome copy ('Welcome to Split Lease!') signals that the human relationship has ended and the bureaucratic one has begun. Freud's 'element of disappointment' activates immediately.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Welcome to Split Lease! Complete your profile to get started.

elements.title: Dignified Surrender: Honoring the Host's Sacrifice During Listing Creation
elements.problem: Listing creation is the peak of instinctual renunciation. The host is converting their private space -- their home, their rooms, their intimate domestic environment -- into a public marketplace artifact. Photos of their bedroom. Descriptions of their amenities. Rules for strangers who will live in their space. Each wizard step demands a deeper surrender of the host's private domain. Freud Ch III: 'it is impossible to ignore the extent to which civilization is built up on renunciation of instinctual gratifications... This cultural privation dominates the whole field of social relations.' The emotional challenge is that the platform treats this as a task (fill out 6 steps) when it is actually a sacrifice (convert something intimate into something transactable). Hosts who stall at listing creation are not lazy or confused -- they are experiencing the peak psychological cost of the entire journey. The user stories confirm: 'Completion percentage is a good host nudge' and 'Pause matters more than delete.' Both acknowledge that listing creation demands emotional management, not just task management.
elements.solution: The listing wizard must treat each step as a dignified exchange, not a form submission. Before each disclosure (photos, descriptions, rules), the platform should acknowledge what the host is giving and show what they will receive. Before the photo step: 'Great photos help vetted professionals find your space -- hosts with 4+ photos get proposals 3x faster.' Before the rules step: 'Your house rules are enforced by the platform. Guests agree to them before they can propose.' The emotional arc is: each surrender is met with an explicit promise that the civilization will honor the sacrifice. The completion indicator is not just a progress bar -- it is a narrative of civilizational investment: 'You have built 67% of your listing. Everything you have entered is saved and ready.' Pause must be frictionless and guilt-free. The tone when a host pauses should be: 'Your listing is saved exactly as you left it. Come back whenever you are ready.'

evidence.quote: Hosts need to know what's unfinished before a listing goes live. A visible progress indicator on the listing card creates just enough friction to get them to finish -- without being in the way.
evidence.insight: The completion percentage is a civilizing mechanism: it makes the host's partial compliance visible. But it must feel like an invitation to continue, not a reminder of what they owe. The emotional charge of the indicator should be encouragement, not guilt.

evidence.quote: It is impossible to ignore the extent to which civilization is built up on renunciation of instinctual gratifications... This 'cultural privation' dominates the whole field of social relations between human beings; we know already that it is the cause of the antagonism against which all civilization has to fight.
evidence.insight: Every incomplete listing wizard is evidence of the antagonism Freud describes. The host feels the privation of converting their private space into public data. The platform must compensate for each privation with a concrete demonstration of civilizational value -- what this specific step will produce for the host.

elements.emotion_rationale: The host needs to feel that creating a listing is an achievement worthy of respect, not a bureaucratic chore -- that their willingness to share their space is valued by the platform and will be rewarded by the marketplace.

do: Acknowledge the effort at each step: 'Nice -- your space details are set. Two more steps to go.'
Show the benefit of each disclosure: 'Hosts with detailed amenity lists get 40% more proposals'
Frame rules as empowerment: 'Your house rules are binding. Guests agree before they can propose.'
Celebrate completion: 'Your listing is live. Vetted professionals can now find your space.'
dont: Use bare imperative language: 'Upload photos.' 'Enter your rules.' 'Set your price.'
Treat the wizard as a form: 'Step 4 of 6: Pricing'
Make the host feel behind: 'Your listing is only 33% complete'
Present photos as just another field -- acknowledge it is the most intimate step
copy_guidelines.example_good: Your space is looking great. Add a few photos so vetted professionals can see what makes it special -- hosts with photos get proposals 3x faster.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Upload at least 4 photos of your space. Supported formats: JPG, PNG. Max file size: 10MB.

animation_feel.feel_description: Each completed wizard step produces a brief, satisfying settle -- the progress bar fills with a smooth pour, and a subtle checkmark blooms beside the step label. The sensation is of building something, not filling out something.

tension_relief.tension_point: Each new wizard step that asks the host to surrender more private information -- especially the photo upload step, which converts visual privacy into a public commodity
tension_relief.relief_point: A concrete, specific benefit statement immediately preceding the ask ('Hosts with photos get 3x more proposals') plus the auto-save indicator ('Everything saved') that assures the host their investment is protected
tension_relief.timing: Benefit statement appears before the input field loads. Auto-save confirmation appears within 2 seconds of any input.

personalization_signals: Reference the agent's assessment: 'Bryant noted your building has great natural light -- photos of that will stand out'
Show comparable listings: 'Similar spaces in Williamsburg listed for $X/month with these features highlighted'
Pre-fill from call data: if the agent noted amenities, pre-check them with a note: 'Based on your call with Bryant'
Show demand: 'X professionals are searching for spaces like yours right now'

anti_patterns.pattern: Treating the photo upload as a routine form field
anti_patterns.reason: Photos of the host's home are the most intimate disclosure in the entire journey. Treating them the same as a dropdown selection for 'building type' ignores the psychological weight of converting visual privacy into public data. The photo step needs distinct emotional framing that acknowledges the significance of this surrender.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Upload photos (minimum 4). Drag and drop or click to browse.

elements.title: Vigilant Gatekeeping: Transforming Stranger Anxiety Into Confident Assessment at Proposal Review
elements.problem: When a guest submits a proposal, the host confronts the primal anxiety that Freud identifies in Ch V: 'men are not gentle, friendly creatures wishing for love... but that a powerful measure of desire for aggression has to be reckoned as part of their instinctual endowment. The result is that their neighbour is to them not only a possible helper or sexual object, but also a temptation to them to gratify their aggressiveness on him.' Every proposal is from a stranger seeking entry to the host's private domain. The host's instinct is distrust. The emotional challenge is not to eliminate this distrust (it is instinctually legitimate) but to transform it from diffuse anxiety into focused, confident assessment. A host who feels anxious about a stranger will freeze or decline. A host who feels equipped to evaluate a stranger will decide with confidence. The user stories confirm: 'A well-structured proposal activates the host to respond. A vague or incomplete one creates friction.'
elements.solution: The proposal experience must convert the host's anxiety into agency. The emotional arc is: alarm (new proposal notification) to assessment (scanning trust signals) to decision (confident accept, counter, or decline). The trust signals must arrive before the terms: the guest's verification status, completed leases, review rating, and stated reason for their stay. The copy around the proposal must frame the host as the decision-maker, not the recipient: 'You have a new proposal. Here is what you need to know about this guest.' The counter-proposal mechanism must feel like negotiation, not confrontation: 'Adjust the terms to fit your needs' rather than 'Decline and counter.' The emotional goal is that the host feels like a gatekeeper who has been given excellent intelligence, not a homeowner answering the door to a stranger.

evidence.quote: A well-structured proposal -- clear dates, schedule, pricing, intent -- activates the host to respond. A vague or incomplete one creates friction.
evidence.insight: The structure of the proposal itself is the emotional intervention. A structured proposal says: 'This stranger has submitted to the same civilizational rules you accepted.' A vague proposal says: 'This stranger has not bothered to organize themselves for your space.' The former reduces instinctual threat; the latter amplifies it.

evidence.quote: The bit of truth behind all this -- one so eagerly denied -- is that men are not gentle, friendly creatures wishing for love... but that a powerful measure of desire for aggression has to be reckoned as part of their instinctual endowment.
evidence.insight: The host's distrust of the guest is not irrational -- it is instinctual. The platform must not try to talk the host out of their vigilance. Instead, it must equip the vigilance with actionable information so the host can transform anxiety into assessment.

elements.emotion_rationale: The host must feel empowered to evaluate and decide, not anxious about a stranger's approach; confidence comes from having sufficient trust evidence to transform instinctual distrust into informed judgment.

do: Lead with trust evidence: 'Verified guest. 3 completed leases. 4.9 avg rating.'
Frame the host as decision-maker: 'You have a new proposal to review'
Show the guest's stated purpose: 'Sarah works at Deloitte and needs a weekday space near Midtown'
Frame counter-proposals as refinement: 'Adjust these terms to work for you'
dont: Lead with terms before trust: 'New proposal: $180/night, 10 weeks, starting March 1'
Use language that pressures acceptance: 'This guest is waiting for your response!'
Frame declining as confrontation: 'Reject this proposal'
Hide the guest's platform history behind a profile link the host must navigate to
copy_guidelines.example_good: Sarah Chen -- Verified, 3 completed leases, 4.9 rating. She works at Deloitte and needs a weekday space near Midtown for 10 weeks starting March 1.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: New proposal received! 10 weeks, $180/night. Respond within 48 hours.

animation_feel.feel_description: The proposal card opens with a calm, measured reveal -- trust signals appear first (a brief stagger, 100ms between each data point), followed by terms. The host's eye is guided from safety to specifics. Nothing flashes or pulses with urgency.

tension_relief.tension_point: The notification that a stranger wants to enter the host's space -- the initial proposal alert
tension_relief.relief_point: The trust block at the top of the proposal: verification badge, completed leases count, review score, and stated purpose -- resolving the 'is this person safe?' question within 3 seconds
tension_relief.timing: Trust evidence must be the first information the host sees when opening a proposal, before any dates, pricing, or terms

personalization_signals: If the guest has stayed with hosts in the same neighborhood, surface that: 'Sarah has stayed with 2 other hosts in Williamsburg'
If this is the host's first proposal, add contextual guidance: 'This is your first proposal. Here is what each section means.'
Show compatibility signals: if the guest's schedule aligns with the host's listing preferences, highlight the match
If the agent has vetted this guest, show: 'Bryant has reviewed this guest's application'

anti_patterns.pattern: Leading the proposal with financial terms before trust evidence
anti_patterns.reason: When the host sees '$180/night for 10 weeks' before knowing anything about the person, they process the terms through an anxiety filter rather than a confidence filter. The financial evaluation cannot happen rationally until the stranger-threat question is resolved. Terms before trust produces defensive calculation; trust before terms produces confident evaluation.
anti_patterns.example_bad: New proposal: $180/night, 10 weeks, March 1 - May 10. View guest profile to learn more.

elements.title: Civilizational Rhythm: Sustaining Comfort Through Predictable Ritual During Active Lease
elements.problem: The active lease is the phase of sustained coexistence with a stranger in the host's private space. Freud Ch V warns: 'Civilized society is perpetually menaced with disintegration through this primary hostility of men towards one another.' The host's anxiety does not resolve when the lease is signed -- it recurs with every stay cycle. Every week the guest occupies the space, the host must re-manage their instinctual anxiety: Is my space being respected? Is the guest following the rules? Are the cleaning standards being maintained? Without structured reassurance mechanisms, this anxiety accumulates silently. A week without a cleaning photo becomes 'the guest is not taking care of my space.' Three days without communication becomes 'something is wrong.' The emotional challenge is that the absence of information is experienced as a threat signal. Freud identifies the solution as 'order: a kind of repetition-compulsion by which it is ordained once for all when, where and how a thing shall be done so that on every similar occasion doubt and hesitation shall be avoided.'
elements.solution: The active lease must feel like a well-run household with a predictable rhythm, not like an ongoing uncertainty. The emotional design centers on ritual confirmation: arrival notification, cleaning photos, micro-review -- the same three beats, in the same order, at the same time relative to each stay cycle. The host should never wonder 'should I check on things?' because the system brings the confirmation to them. When rituals are completed (cleaning photos submitted, arrival confirmed), the emotional register is quiet satisfaction: 'All clear. Your space is in good hands.' When rituals are delayed, the register is neutral informational: 'Cleaning photos pending -- we have reminded your guest.' The platform handles the follow-up; the host never chases. The cumulative effect is that over 13+ weekly stays, the rhythm becomes internalized: the host stops worrying because the ritual has never failed them.

evidence.quote: Order is a kind of repetition-compulsion by which it is ordained once for all when, where and how a thing shall be done so that on every similar occasion doubt and hesitation shall be avoided. The benefits of order are incontestable: it enables us to use space and time to the best advantage, while saving expenditure of mental energy.
evidence.insight: The stay cycle rituals (arrival confirmation, cleaning photos, micro-review) are Freud's 'order' made concrete. Each repetition confirms that the civilizational structure is holding, reducing the host's mental energy expenditure on worry and doubt about the stranger in their space.

evidence.quote: Urgency should surface first on the dashboard. Unread proposals, pending actions, incomplete listings -- that's what a host needs to see the moment they log in.
evidence.insight: Extended to active lease: the host needs to see the latest ritual confirmation. Did the guest confirm arrival? Were cleaning photos submitted? The dashboard must surface this health information with the same structured clarity as proposal notifications -- but the emotional register should be comfort, not urgency.

elements.emotion_rationale: During an active lease, the host's highest-value emotional state is sustained calm -- the confidence that their space is being respected without needing to monitor it actively. Ritual predictability produces this calm; informational voids destroy it.

do: State completions plainly: 'Guest confirmed arrival for Jan 15-18. All clear.'
Frame cleaning photos as evidence of respect: 'Sarah submitted cleaning photos. Your space looks great.'
Surface absence neutrally: 'Cleaning photos not yet submitted. We have reminded Sarah.'
Show cumulative reassurance: '8 of 10 stays completed. No issues flagged.'
dont: Over-celebrate routine compliance: 'Amazing! Your guest submitted cleaning photos!'
Alarm on delayed rituals: 'WARNING: Cleaning photos not received!'
Require host action for routine confirmations: 'Please confirm you reviewed the cleaning photos'
Introduce novelty into the ritual: changing the format, adding new steps, or rearranging the card layout mid-lease
copy_guidelines.example_good: Stay 8 of 10 complete. Cleaning photos submitted. All clear.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Attention! Your guest's latest stay just ended. Have you checked their cleaning photos yet? Review now!

animation_feel.feel_description: Ritual completions appear as quiet state changes -- a status badge sliding smoothly from 'In Progress' to 'Complete,' a green check fading in beside a photo grid. The sensation is of a clock ticking reliably, not of events demanding attention.

tension_relief.tension_point: The window between a guest's expected departure and the submission of cleaning photos -- the host imagines mess, damage, or disregard
tension_relief.relief_point: The cleaning photo thumbnail grid appearing on the stay card, confirming the space was left in good condition
tension_relief.timing: Photos should appear on the host's dashboard within minutes of submission. If delayed beyond 12 hours post-departure, the platform's 'we have reminded your guest' message fills the void before anxiety crystallizes.

personalization_signals: Show this guest's ritual completion rate: 'Sarah has submitted cleaning photos for all 7 previous stays'
Reference the specific lease progress: 'Stay 8 of 10 -- two stays remaining'
If the host previously flagged an issue, show resolution: 'The kitchen concern from Stay 5 has not recurred'
Surface cumulative positive patterns: 'All cleaning photos have been on time this lease'

anti_patterns.pattern: Treating missed rituals with the same urgency as critical alerts
anti_patterns.reason: A missed cleaning photo is an informational gap, not an emergency. If the platform treats it with red alerts and exclamation marks, it transforms a manageable absence into a crisis that amplifies the host's instinctual anxiety about the stranger. Neutral, factual language ('pending -- we have reminded your guest') manages the gap without inflaming it.
anti_patterns.example_bad: ALERT: Cleaning photos not received for this stay! Contact your guest immediately.

elements.title: Civilizational Justice: Making Platform Constraints Feel Like Mutual Protection
elements.problem: The platform enforces rules at multiple touchpoints: confirmation dialogs, date change approvals, mutual consent requirements. The host experiences these as constraints on their autonomy -- 'I cannot change dates without asking.' Freud Ch III identifies the 'first requisite of culture' as 'justice -- that is, the assurance that a law once made will not be broken in favour of any individual.' But justice is only perceived as justice when both sides of the constraint are visible. A host who sees only their own constraint ('you must wait for approval') experiences oppression. A host who sees both sides simultaneously ('the guest also cannot change dates without your approval') experiences protection. The emotional challenge is that platform rules, presented one-sidedly, activate the host's instinctual revolt against civilization. L1 (works-006) prescribes making mediation feel like justice; L3 (looks-007) prescribes the visual protection surface. The feels layer must define the emotional register that makes these constraints feel like mutual safety.
elements.solution: Every platform rule must be presented with an emotional frame that leads with protection before revealing constraint. The emotional sequence is: (1) 'You are protected' (safety first), (2) 'Here is how -- this rule applies equally to both of you' (justice visible), (3) 'What would you like to do?' (agency preserved). The copy must never lead with the restriction. The tone must be steady and warm -- the voice of a fair referee, not a bureaucratic gatekeeper. When the host encounters a constraint, the first thing they should feel is: 'this system has my back.' The emotional arc over time: after encountering 3-4 constraint surfaces that consistently lead with protection, the host develops a Pavlovian trust response to the warm purple protection surface (L3 looks-007). The platform's rules begin to feel like a shield rather than a cage.

evidence.quote: The first requisite of culture, therefore, is justice -- that is, the assurance that a law once made will not be broken in favour of any individual.
evidence.insight: Platform rules are Freud's 'law.' But a law perceived as one-sided feels unjust regardless of its actual fairness. The emotional design must ensure the host perceives justice (bidirectional fairness) not bureaucracy (one-sided constraint) at every enforcement point.

evidence.quote: The park analogy holds -- you check availability before committing. A message action reduces abandonment when someone isn't ready for a proposal. Having the option is better than having no action at all.
evidence.insight: The park analogy is fundamentally about reducing the emotional intensity of civilizational demand. Constraint surfaces should feel like park benches -- warm, inviting, a place to pause and assess -- not like courtrooms where judgment is being rendered.

elements.emotion_rationale: When the host encounters a platform-enforced constraint, the target emotion is safety -- the feeling that this rule exists specifically to protect them and their space, not to control them.

do: Lead with protection: 'Both parties are protected from unexpected changes'
Show both sides in parallel: 'The guest cannot change dates without your approval. You also cannot change dates without theirs.'
Frame the CTA as agency: 'Confirm this date change request' -- the host is acting, not complying
Use human language: 'This keeps things fair for both of you'
dont: Lead with the restriction: 'Date changes require mutual approval'
Use legal language: 'Per the lease agreement, both parties must consent'
Use punitive framing: 'Failure to respond within 48 hours will result in...'
Present the constraint without explaining its reciprocal benefit
copy_guidelines.example_good: Both parties are protected. The guest cannot change dates without your approval, and you cannot change dates without theirs. This keeps things fair.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Date changes require mutual approval. Please wait for the guest to confirm before proceeding.

animation_feel.feel_description: The protection surface appears with a gentle fade over a subtle backdrop -- not the heavy modal overlay of a warning dialog, but a warm, purple-tinted surface that feels like a reassuring aside. It settles into view rather than interrupting.

tension_relief.tension_point: The moment the host encounters a constraint on their autonomy -- 'I cannot do this without asking the guest'
tension_relief.relief_point: Seeing immediately that the guest also cannot do this without asking the host -- the constraint is mutual, not one-directional
tension_relief.timing: The bidirectional explanation must appear simultaneously with the constraint, not after. The host should never experience the constraint alone, even for a second.

personalization_signals: Reference the specific guest: 'Sarah also cannot change your agreed schedule without your approval'
If this is the first time the host encounters this constraint, add a brief explanation: 'This is how Split Lease keeps both hosts and guests protected'
Show the host's agent as a fallback: 'If you need help, Bryant is available'
After multiple encounters, simplify: the host has learned the pattern, so the bidirectional explanation can be briefer

anti_patterns.pattern: Presenting platform rules as one-sided restrictions on the host
anti_patterns.reason: A host who repeatedly encounters rules framed as 'you cannot' without seeing the reciprocal 'they also cannot' develops Freud's 'antagonism against civilization.' They begin to see the platform as an authority that controls them rather than a system that protects them. The emotional damage accumulates across multiple encounters and crystallizes at retention as a reason not to re-list.
anti_patterns.example_bad: You must wait for guest approval before changing dates. The guest has been notified.

elements.title: Retrospective Worth: Counteracting the Narcissism of Minor Differences at Retention
elements.problem: Retention is where the host's entire civilizational participation is retroactively evaluated. Freud Ch V introduces 'the narcissism of minor differences' -- the psychological tendency to anchor on small, proximate grievances rather than large, cumulative benefits. A host who earned $12,000 across 12 successful stays but had one difficult week will, in retrospect, disproportionately weight the difficult week. The emotional challenge is that the host's natural memory architecture favors negative exceptions over positive patterns. Without a structured counter-narrative, the retrospective assessment defaults to dissatisfaction. The user stories document's principle about Pause vs. Delete applies: the host who pauses is psychologically closer to re-entry than the one who deletes. But neither Pause nor Delete addresses the core emotional problem: the host must feel, at the moment of the retention decision, that their civilizational participation was net-positive. The weakest phase in the library (44 mentions vs. 152 for active lease), retention is where emotional design has the most untapped leverage.
elements.solution: The retention moment must be designed as a celebration of cumulative achievement, not a decision about future commitment. Before the host sees any prompt to re-list, they should see their full hosting record presented as a narrative of civilizational worth: total earnings (large, in the evidence register), successful stays, average rating, hosting tenure. The emotional arc is: reflection (see what you built) to recognition (this was a meaningful achievement) to continuation (keep building). The re-listing CTA must use continuation language ('Continue Hosting') not restart language ('Create New Listing'). The emotional design must counteract Freud's narcissism of minor differences by embedding any negative memory within the larger positive pattern. A single bad stay in the context of '$12,000 earned across 12 successful stays' feels like an exception, not the rule. The key emotional insight: do not ask the host 'do you want to host again?' Ask them 'look at what you have built -- do you want to keep building?'

evidence.quote: Civilized man has exchanged some part of his chances of happiness for a measure of security.
evidence.insight: At retention, the host re-evaluates whether the security (income, vetted guests, platform protection) was worth the happiness sacrificed (privacy, autonomy, effort). The emotional design must make the security tangible and cumulative, so the retrospective calculation favors continuation.

evidence.quote: Pause preserves the work, keeps the door open, and costs nothing. Delete is a one-way door that creates regret.
evidence.insight: The emotional weight of Pause vs. Delete is about preserving the host's civilizational investment. But the feels layer adds: even before the host reaches the Pause/Delete choice, their emotional state must be shaped by seeing the cumulative value of what they would be pausing or deleting. The investment must be visible before the decision is presented.

evidence.quote: There is an advantage, not to be undervalued, in the existence of smaller communities, through which the aggressive instinct can find an outlet in enmity towards those outside the group.
evidence.insight: A host who sees themselves as part of a hosting community -- with a track record, milestones, and a shared identity -- directs their accumulated frustrations outward (toward competitors, toward difficult guests as a category) rather than inward (toward the platform). Community identity is the emotional infrastructure of retention.

elements.emotion_rationale: The host must feel, at the retention moment, that their hosting record is a genuine achievement -- not just a transaction history but a narrative of cumulative civilizational contribution that would be costly to abandon.

do: Lead with the largest positive number: '$12,400 earned since you started hosting'
Frame hosting as a trajectory: 'Your 3rd lease. 28 successful stays. 4.8 average rating.'
Use continuation language: 'Continue Hosting' -- one tap, no wizard
Acknowledge the investment: 'Your listing, reviews, and hosting record are all preserved'
dont: Present re-listing as a new decision: 'Ready to host again? Create a new listing'
Surface negative data in the retention summary: missed stays, disputes, low ratings
Use urgency: 'Don't lose your hosting streak!'
Introduce new demands at the retention moment: 'Before you re-list, please update your photos'
copy_guidelines.example_good: You have earned $12,400 across 28 successful stays with a 4.8 average rating. Your listing is ready whenever you are.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Your last lease has ended. Would you like to create a new listing? Update your photos and pricing to get started.

animation_feel.feel_description: The Hosting Summary metrics appear with a staggered entrance -- total earnings first (largest), then supporting metrics, then the trajectory timeline. Each number arrives with a subtle scale-up from 90% to 100%, creating a feeling of revelation and weight. The CTA button pulses once with a soft purple glow after the metrics settle.

tension_relief.tension_point: The moment the lease ends and the host faces the implicit question: 'Was this worth it? Should I do it again?'
tension_relief.relief_point: The Hosting Summary presenting the cumulative evidence that the civilizational exchange was net-positive, before the host's narcissism of minor differences can anchor on the worst memory
tension_relief.timing: The Hosting Summary should appear 24 hours after the final stay completes -- giving the host time to decompress but not enough time for negative retrospection to crystallize. The summary must appear before any re-listing prompt.

personalization_signals: Show the specific earnings figure, not an average or estimate
Reference the host's specific guests by name: '3 guests hosted: Sarah, Marcus, and Lee'
If the host's rating improved over time, highlight the trajectory: 'Your rating has improved from 4.5 to 4.9 across your hosting record'
For experienced hosts, show growth: 'You earned 22% more this lease than your previous one'

anti_patterns.pattern: Framing re-listing as a new commitment rather than a continuation
anti_patterns.reason: If the host perceives re-listing as starting over (new wizard, new setup, new commitment), the psychological cost of re-entry approximates the original renunciation gradient. Freud: 'the inertia of libido, its disinclination to relinquish an old position in favour of a new one.' The 'old position' is not hosting; re-listing must feel like staying in the current position (hosting), not moving to a new one.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Your lease has ended. Ready to host again? Set up your new listing to start receiving proposals.
